cell.html: Coeus was not a god but in fact a titan .
cell.text: Coeus was not a god but in fact a titan .

cell.html: Erlang Shen is often depicted with an extra 'truth-seeing' eye in the centre of his head.
cell.text: Erlang Shen is often depicted with an extra 'truth-seeing' eye in the centre of his head.

cell.html: Offerings were given to Fabulinus when a child spoke its first words because he was the god that taught children to speak.
cell.text: Offerings were given to Fabulinus when a child spoke its first words because he was the god that taught children to speak.

cell.html: Odin had sacrificed his eye in Mímir's Well which granted him wisdom and the power to see into the future. Mímir himself was said to have been the wisest of the gods.
cell.text: Odin had sacrificed his eye in Mímir's Well which granted him wisdom and the power to see into the future. Mímir himself was said to have been the wisest of the gods.

cell.html: Ogma was thought to have invented the first Irish alphabet , Ogham .
cell.text: Ogma was thought to have invented the first Irish alphabet , Ogham .

cell.html: Omoikane's name literally means Serving One's Thoughts .
cell.text: Omoikane's name literally means Serving One's Thoughts .

cell.html: Thoth became credited by the ancient Egyptians as the inventor of writing , and was also considered to have been the scribe of the underworld .
cell.text: Thoth became credited by the ancient Egyptians as the inventor of writing , and was also considered to have been the scribe of the underworld .

cell.html: Saraswati is the first of the three great goddesses of Hinduism . She is the Goddess of Knowledge and all literary arts including music, arts, and speech.
cell.text: Saraswati is the first of the three great goddesses of Hinduism . She is the Goddess of Knowledge and all literary arts including music, arts, and speech.

context.text: Knowledge deity - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Name Place and Religion of Origin Notes

entity.htmlSnippet:
NamePlace and Religion of OriginNotes
AnulapPolynesian mythology (specifically Micronesia)
CoeusGreek mythologyCoeus was not a god but in fact a titan.
Erlang ShenChinese mythologyErlang Shen is often depicted with an extra 'truth-seeing' eye in the centre of his head.
FabulinusRoman mythologyOfferings were given to Fabulinus when a child spoke its first words because he was the god that taught children to speak.
Odin, MímirNorse mythologyOdin had sacrificed his eye in Mímir's Well which granted him wisdom and the power to see into the future. Mímir himself was said to have been the wisest of the gods.
OgmaIrish mythologyOgma was thought to have invented the first Irish alphabet, Ogham.
OmoikaneShintoismOmoikane's name literally means Serving One's Thoughts.
ThothEgyptian mythologyThoth became credited by the ancient Egyptians as the inventor of writing, and was also considered to have been the scribe of the underworld.
SaraswatiIndian mythologySaraswati is the first of the three great goddesses of Hinduism. She is the Goddess of Knowledge and all literary arts including music, arts, and speech.
